titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William O. Douglas Collection 1920-1980
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by William Huntington, 2010

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by William Huntington2010
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS ( Describing Archives: A Content Standard).

did.unittitle: William O. Douglas Collection
did.abstract: The William O. Douglas Collection contains the former Supreme Court Justice’s research materials, reports to Congress, book manuscripts, published articles, law practice records, correspondence with friends and associates, and materials relating to his association with Whitman College.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Douglas was born in Maine Township, Minnesota. His family moved to California, and then Cleveland, Washington. His father died in Portland, Oregon in 1904, when he was only six years old. In 1916, Douglas won a scholarship to Whitman College in Walla Walla, Washington. He taught at Yakima High School for two years before attending Yale Law School, graduating in 1925. After practicing law and teaching at Yale, he joined the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, becoming Chairman in 1937. He finally was appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Supreme Court in 1939.

During his tenure on the bench, Justice Douglas achieved a number of records and distinctions. Along with the longevity record, he also established the records for the most opinions written, the most dissents written, the most speeches given, and the most books authored by any member of the Supreme Court. He also achieved a few less savory records, such as the most wives (four), the most divorces while on the bench (three), and the most attempts at impeachment (three). None of these records have been surpassed.

scopecontent.p: The William O. Douglas Collection includes speeches, research materials, correspondence, postcards, forestry management, reports to Congress, invitations, book manuscripts, publications, newspaper clippings, contracts, law practice records, articles and magazines about conservation, correspondence with Len Jansen, and materials collected by Whitman College staff.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. for copyright not held by Whitman College.

prefercite.p: William O. Douglas Collection, Whitman College and Northwest Archives.

acqinfo.p: Donated to the Whitman College and Northwest Archives by Leonard F. Jansen, 1995; additional material donated by David Danelski in 1998; material collected by Whitman College.

dsc.p: The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection.
